conclusion: I'll solve this problem step-by-step by analyzing the velocity-time graph to find the acceleration during the time interval from 1 to 3 seconds.
The graph shows velocity (v) in m/s on the vertical axis against time (t) in seconds on the horizontal axis.
Constant velocity of 2 m/s from 0 to 1 second.
Linear decrease in velocity from 2 m/s at t=1s to -2 m/s at t=3s.
Constant velocity of -2 m/s after t=3s.
Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity with respect to time, which can be calculated as: a = Δv/Δt.

premise: Initial velocity (at t=1s): v₁ = 2 m/s. Final velocity (at t=3s): v₂ = -2 m/s. Time interval: Δt = 3s - 1s = 2s.
The v-t graph has a constant negative slope during this time interval. The slope of the v-t graph represents acceleration.
conclusion: The velocity changes from 2 m/s to -2 m/s (a change of 4 m/s) over 2 seconds, giving us a slope of -2 m/s², which confirms our calculation.
The acceleration of the particle during the time interval from 1 to 3 seconds is -2 m/s².
